awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Rethinking Side Channel Security on Untrusted Operating Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent advances of isolated execution technologies, especially the emergence of Intel Software Guard eXtension (SGX), revolutionize the model of computer security and empower programs with sensitive data and code to be shielded from untrusted operating systems. However, their security guarantees have not yet been thoroughly investigated against the notorious vector of information leakage side-channel attacks. It is conceivable that side-channel attacks with full control of the underlying operating system are more diverse, efficient and robust than those from unprivileged programs. As a result, side-channel security, or lack thereof, will significantly impact the security promises offered by such technologies.

The objective of the research project is to fully understand risks of side-channel information leakage in such isolated execution environments on untrusted operating systems, by (1) identifying new side-channel attack vectors systematically and automatically using model checking techniques, (2) examining new capabilities of privileged attackers that may lead to more robust and efficient side-channel attacks, and (3) advancing our understanding of the effectiveness of potential solutions to side-channel threats in the underlying context. The study conceptualizes new frameworks for systematically evaluating side-channel security of computer systems, and also provides new insights on side-channel vulnerabilities on untrusted operating systems. More broadly, the project will offer guidelines for industry practices of SGX and an integration of the PI?s research into STEM education.

por.por_cntn:
This research project has successfully helped reshape the research directions of side-channel security on Intel’s Software Guard Extension. SGX is a novel technology designed to protect both the confidentiality and integrity of the enclave code and data against compromised operating systems. But one issue not addressed by SGX is the side channels. This project has made the following contribution to improving the understanding of side channels on SGX: (1) The project systematically studies side-channel attack vectors on SGX. (2) The project has identified several novel methods of conducting side-channel attacks from privileged systems and some new and important victims (e.g., the SSL/TLS protocol) of such attacks in the SGX context. (3) The project has explored several novel compiler-assisted approaches that automatically instrument enclave binaries to enable runtime detection of side-channel attacks from within the enclave program itself. (4) The project has explored methods of conducting dynamic analysis (e.g., DCFG analysis and symbolic execution) to detect vulnerabilities in enclave binaries. These findings have helped the academic research community and industry partners understand not only how SGX enclaves are vulnerable to side-channel attacks and what solutions may work and what may not. It has led to significant philosophy changes in the SGX side-channel defenses and empirically demonstrated the viability of some solutions.

Broader societal impacts of the project include the following three aspects: First, the project has allowed the PI to mentor three graduate students and two undergraduate students. For the graduate students, the project enables them to initially explore their research interests, improve their ability to conduct system security research, and establish their reputation in the field of system security through publication at top-tier conferences. After graduation, they will become researchers or engineers who have deep knowledge of system security and side-channel security that will be very valuable to the entire society. With the REU supplement support, the PI also recruited one female undergraduate student from historically underrepresented ethnic groups through collaboration with the LSAMP Program.  The research experience has enabled the undergraduate students to explore the world of security research, improved their programming skills, and their determination of participating in STEM education.

Second, the project has enriched the PI’s classroom teaching. Some of the materials have been integrated into the courses taught by the PI. For example, the security model of Intel SGX has been introduced in the PI's seminar course and results of one research paper from the project has been used to develop a lab module in the PI’s network security course.


Third, the project has promoted the awareness of side-channel threats to researcher, software and hardware vendors, and the general public. The results of the research have been disseminated through peer-review conference publications. Particularly, 11 papers have been published at top-tier or high-profile security conferences. Besides, some technical presentations describing these research results have been recorded and made available online. The research results have also been disseminated by the PI through tutorials at high-profile conferences (e.g., ACM CCS), presentations at local workshops, and invited talks at Intel and other industry vendors. One paper partially supported by this research project that describes Spectre-like attacks against SGX has been made available to the public in the form of a website and open-source project. Multiple online media have reported this finding, which has raised the public awareness of SGX side channels and motivated the industry vendors to take steps towards adopting effective solutions.

 

 


Last Modified: 05/05/2018
Modified by: Yinqian Zhang
